title: Characteristics of Resistance Training-Based Protocols in Older Adults With Sarcopenic Obesity: A Scoping Review

sections.abstract:
Due to their differing etiologies and conse-
quences, it has been proposed that the term Bsarcopenia^
should revert to its original definition of age-related muscle
mass declines, with a separate term, Bdynapenia^,d e s c r i b i n g
muscle strength and function declines. There is increasing
interest in the interactions of sarcopenia and dynapenia with
obesity. Despite an apparent protective effect of obesity on
fracture, increased adiposity may compromise bone health,
and the presence of sarcopenia and/or dynapenia
(Bsarcopenic obesity^ and Bdynapenic obesity ^) may exac-
erbate the risk of falls and fracture in obese older adults.
Weight loss interventions are likely to be beneficial for older
adults with sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity but may result
in further reductions in muscle and bone health. The addi-
tion of exercise including progressive resistance training and
nutritional strategies, including protein and vitamin D sup-
plementation, may optimise body composition and muscle
function outcomes thereby reducing falls and fracture risk in
this population.
Keywords Sarcopenia . Dynapenia . Obesity . Falls .
Fractures . Lifestyle
sections.introduction:
Ageing is associated with progre ssive declines in the skeletal
muscle mass and quality and concomitant increases in fat mass,
which have significant metabolic and functional consequences
[1]. Falls and fracture are a common concern for many older
people, with low muscle mass ( Bsarcopenia^) and muscle
strength (Bdynapenia^) both implicated as risk factors for these
outcomes. However, when combined with obesity (Bsarcopenic
obesity^ or Bdynapenic obesity^), the associations are unclear
due to a lack of prospective studies and controversy on the role
of fat mass in falls and fracture risk [ 2]. Obese older people
have higher fall risk than non-obese but may have reduced
fracture risk due to greater bone strength and/or the protective
effect of higher amounts of soft tissue. Nevertheless, with the
This article is part of the Topical Collection on Nutrition, Exercise, and
Lifestyle in Osteoporosis
* David Scott

Robin M. Daly

Kerrie.Sanders@acu.edu.au
Peter R. Ebeling
peter.ebeling@monash.edu
1 Department of Medicine, School of Clinical Sciences at Monash
Health, Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences, Monash
Medical Centre, Monash University, 246 Clayton Road,
Clayton, VIC, Australia 3168
2 Melbourne Medical School (Western Campus) and Australian
Institute for Musculoskeletal Science, Sunshine Hospital, The
University of Melbourne, 176 Furlong Road, St Albans, VIC,
Australia 3021
3 Centre for Physical Activity and Nutrition Research, School of
Exercise and Nutrition Sciences, Deakin University, 221 Burwood
Highway, Burwood, VIC, Australia 3125
4 Institute for Health and Ageing, Australian Catholic University,
Level 6, 215 Spring Street, Melbourne, VIC, Australia 3000
Curr Osteoporos Rep
DOI 10.1007/s11914-015-0274-z


prevalence of obesity in older populations increasing, most
fractures now occur in overweight and obese older adults [ 3],
and so identifying risk factors within this population is impor-
tant. This review summary provides a background on
sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity, together with the less well-
established concepts of dynapenia and dynapenic obesity, their
associations with fall and fracture risk, and the role of lifestyle
interventions in preventing these outcomes.
Sarcopenia
The term sarcopenia, from the Greek for Bpoverty of flesh ^,
was first proposed as a descriptor for age-related muscle
wasting by Irwin Rosenberg in 1988 [ 4]. The first operational
definition was provided by Baumgartner and colleagues in
1998, who defined sarcopenia as dual-energy X-ray absorpti-
ometry (DXA)-determined appendicular lean mass (ALM; in
kg)/height (m
2) (ALM/Ht2) less than two standard deviations
below the mean of a young adult reference group [ 5]. While
this definition has been most commonly used to diagnose
sarcopenia, definitions normalised for body weight, body fat,
and BMI have also been proposed given that ALM/Ht
2 may
underestimate sarcopenia prevalence in obese individuals [ 6].
The resulting lack of standardisation and poor agreement be-
tween sarcopenia definitions has been recognised as a major
barrier to determining prevalence and consequences of
sarcopenia and its inclusion in routine clinical practice [ 7].
In order to address these issues, several expert groups have
proposed consensus definitions including measurements and
thresholds relevant to clinical settings [8–11]. For instance, the
European Working Group on Sarcopenia for Older People
(EWGSOP) defines sarcopenia as the presence of low muscle
mass in addition to low muscle strength and/or gait speed [ 8].
Consensus definitions to date have been based on expert opin-
ion, and the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health
Biomarkers Consortium Sarcopenia Project is the first to pro-
vide evidence-based thresholds using muscle mass and hand
grip strength data from nine international cohort studies [ 12•].
Although a single clinical definition of sarcopenia is not
recognised globally, it is evident that most experts now view
sarcopenia as a multidimensional condition involving age-
related declines in muscle mass, strength and function. How-
ever, in recent years, there has been support for considering
muscle mass and strength declines as separate processes, and
for the purposes of this review, sarcopenia will be defined as
age-related loss of muscle mass only.
Dynapenia
Longitudinal studies have disproved the concept that declines
in muscle mass with age are the primary cause of muscle
strength and function deficits [ 13, 14]. The faster rate of de-
cline in strength with age appears to be a result of declines in
Bmuscle quality ^ which may be attributable to age-related
changes in neurologic and skeletal muscle factors including
a loss of motor neurons, neuromuscular transmission, muscle
fibre morphology, and adipose tissue infiltration between
muscles and muscle fascicles (inter- and intra-muscular adi-
pose tissue; IMAT) [ 15]. Furthermore, low muscle strength
has been shown to be a stronger and more consistent predictor
of functional decline, falls and mortality than low muscle mass
[16]. In 2008, Clark and Manini suggested that loss of muscle
strength and/or mechanical power, termed dynapenia (from
the Greek for Bpoverty of strength ^), should be considered a
separate, and potentially more functionally relevant, condition
than sarcopenia [ 17]. Clark and Manini subsequently pro-
posed an algorithm for defining dynapenia including measure-
ments of hand grip and knee extension strength, with subse-
quent investigations to determine neurological or muscular
causation of dynapenia [ 18•]. However, currently, an opera-
tional definition of dynapenia does not exist and the term itself
has not been widely adopted perhaps owing to the fact that
strength and function remain incorporated in current
sarcopenia definitions.
Sarcopenic and Dynapenic Obesity
Low muscle mass relative to fat mass was first described as
sarcopenic obesity by Heber and colleagues in 1996 [ 19].
Obesity is independently associated with poor physical func-
tion in older adults [ 20, 21] but may also contribute to system-
ic low-grade inflammation which can exacerbate muscle loss
leading to sarcopenia. A synergistic effect may occur in which
sarcopenia contributes to further gains in fat mass through a
reduction in physical activity and resting energy expenditure
[1]. Similar to research into sarcopenia itself, early studies of
sarcopenic obesity focused on low muscle mass [ 22], but
Stenholm and colleagues later proposed that the sarcopenic
component should include an assessment of muscle strength,
rather than muscle mass [ 23], and some research groups have
now adopted the term dynapenic obesity to describe low mus-
cle strength in obesity [ 24–27].
Currently, however, there is no consensus on the definition
or diagnosis of sarcopenic or dynapenic obesity and these are
urgently required if researchers are to provide comparable prev-
alence and outcome data and promote assessment of these con-
ditions in the clinic. Indeed, prevalence estimates for sarcopenic
obesity range from 4 to 94 % in N ational Health and Nutrition
Examination Survey (NHANES) participants according to pre-
viously published definitions of sarcopenic obesity [28]. Table1
provides a summary of potential operational definitions accord-
ing to current consensus definitions of sarcopenia and research
into sarcopenic obesity. It should be noted that Manini and
Curr Osteoporos Rep


Clark recommend knee extension strength as a criterion for
dynapenia given its relevance to mobility but acknowledge that
this measurement may be diffic ult in clinical settings and that
sufficient data is unavailable to establish cut-points [18•]. There
is also no consensus on definitions of obesity, which may be
defined using either anthropometric [29] or imaging techniques,
but cut-points of around 30 and 40 % for DXA-assessed body
fat percentage are commonly proposed for men and women,
respectively [30, 31].
Sarcopenic and Dynapenic Obesity and Their
Association with Falls and Fractures
Sarcopenia and dynapenia are recognised as risk factors
for falls and fractures as higher skeletal muscle mass and
strength have been associated with greater physical per-
formance [ 32, 33] and bone health [ 33–35] in older peo-
ple. However, several studies indicate a sex-specific effect
of low muscle mass, with fall and fracture risk increased
for men but not women with sarcopenia [ 5, 33, 36, 37]. In
the New Mexico Elder Health Survey, the likelihood for a
past-year fall was 2.5-fold greater for men with sarcopenia
(defined by ALM/Ht
2) than men without sarcopenia, but
there was no association for women [ 5]. Conversely, poor
hand grip strength [ 38, 39] and lower-limb function [ 40,
41] appear to be consistent predictors of falls and frac-
tures in both sexes and so indicators of dynapenia may be
preferential to sarcopenia for estimating fall and fracture
risk in older adults.
Over the past two decades, there has been considerable
research into the impact of adiposity on fall and fracture
risk in obesity. Obese individuals appear to fall 10 –50 %
more often than normal weight individuals but do not
necessarily have increased in jury (e.g., fracture) rates
from falls, particularly at high levels of adiposity [ 42,
43]. This has been attributed to protection against frac-
tures derived from increased soft-tissue padding and/or
higher BMD [ 44, 45], but recent evidence challenges the
notion that obesity confers improved bone strength and
reduced fracture risk. There may actually be an increased
risk for fracture at certain sites in obese individuals [ 44,
46], and this may be explained by the fact that increases
in BMD and microarchitecture are not proportionate to
increases in fat mass [ 47•]. For example, after adjustment
for femoral neck BMD, the relative risk of any, vertebral,
or upper-limb, fracture may increase in older women by
over 20 % per SD increase in BMI [ 45]. Adipose tissue
distribution may also influenc e fracture risk. Overweight
and obese men with high visceral adipose tissue have
been shown to have poorer bone microarchitecture and
bone mechanical properties, including 7 % lower distal
radius volumetric BMD, com pared to those with low vis-
ceral adipose tissue [ 48]. Similarly, IMAT is an indepen-
dent predictor of falls and fractures in older adults
[49–51], with one study reporting that IMAT accounts
for the association between poor muscle function and 6-
year incident hip fractures [ 52]. The effect of these ectop-
ic fat depots on bone health and fracture risk may be
mediated by their pro-inflammatory nature [ 53]. Based
on the available evidence, it is unclear whether the pres-
ence of obesity offsets or exacerbates the risk of fracture
in individuals with sarcopenia and dynapenia. Neverthe-
less, it would be expected that, at least in comparison to
obese alone individuals, sarcopenic and dynapenic obese
older adults are at increased risk for fractures.
To date, few studies have directly assessed the associ-
ation between sarcopenic or dynapenic obesity with fall

Curr Osteoporos Rep


and fracture risk. While several studies have reported that
sarcopenic obesity is associated with worse physical func-
tioning than either sarcopenia or obesity alone [ 22,
54–56], others have reported no synergistic effect of low
muscle mass and increased fat mass on functional out-
comes [ 26, 57, 58]. These inconsistent findings are likely
due to variation in measurement techniques and thresh-
olds used to define sarcopenic obesity. On the other hand,
low muscle strength combined with obesity has been con-
sistently associated with increased prevalence and inci-
dence of mobility limitations [ 59–61]. Furthermore, sev-
eral studies have reported that dynapenic obese older
adults demonstrate slower gait speed and worse self-
reported mobility and disability than either dynapenic or
obese alone groups [ 24, 27, 62]. Dynapenia and obesity
may have multiplicative rather than additive interactions,
with approximately two-fold g reater activity of daily liv-
ing deficits in dynapenic obese compared to dynapenic
non-obese older Koreans [ 63]. To our knowledge, only
one study has directly compared the effects of dynapenic
obesity and sarcopenic obesity on physical performance
[26]. We recently demonstrated that compared to non-
dynapenic, non-obese older adults, dynapenic obese older
adults had approximately 30 –50 % greater 5-year increase
in scores (indicating worsening performance) for a phys-
iological fall risk assessment [ 26]. However, there was no
difference in change in fall risk scores for sarcopenic
obese and non-sarcopenic non-obese participants during
t h es a m et i m e[ 26].
Few studies have examined associations of sarcopenic obe-
sity with falls, and none have assessed incident fall risk. In the
New Mexico Elder Health Survey, sarcopenic obesity was
associated with an increased likelihood of falls in the past year
in men (OR 3.34, 95% CI 1.37 –8.26), but not women [ 54],
which is consistent with the previously mentioned sex-
specific associations of sarcopenia with falls. In older adults
participating in a fall prevention trial, those classified as
sarcopenic obese had the highest (albeit non-significant) num-
ber of falls in the previous 12 months (1.8 vs 1.2, 1.3 and 1.2
for obese alone, non-sarcopenic non-obese, and sarcopenic
alone, respectively). Similarly, in Taiwanese older adults,
sarcopenic obesity was associated with a two-fold increased
risk of past year falls. However, since this study defined
sarcopenia using the EWGSOP definition, it is unclear wheth-
er this association was explained by low muscle mass and/or
low muscle strength or physical performance [ 64]. Unfortu-
nately no studies have examined the association of dynapenic
obesity with falls to provide insight into this relationship.
Furthermore, to our knowledge, no studies have examined
sarcopenic or dynapenic obesity in the context of fracture
outcomes. Sarcopenic obese individuals do demonstrate a
higher prevalence of femoral neck osteoporosis (17 %) com-
pared to non-sarcopenic non-obese (12 %) and obese alone
(7 %), but not sarcopenic alone (22 %) [ 30]. This is consistent
with the
sections.results:
of a small study suggesting that obesity offers
some protection against low BMD in sarcopenic women [ 65].
Prospective studies are required to determine the effects of
interactions of sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity with fall
and fracture risk, but, given their independent associations
with these outcomes, it is likely that lifestyle interventions
targeting improvements in muscle mass and/or strength with
reductions in fat mass will be beneficial.
Lifestyle Interventions
Exercise and nutrition interventions including progressive re-
sistance training, protein and vitamin D supplementation have
beneficial effects for components of sarcopenia, dynapenia
and obesity, as well as for fall and fracture risk in older adults.
The following section provides a brief overview of the evi-
dence for the key role of lifestyle interventions in addressing
these outcomes.
Exercise
Exercise, particularly progressive resistance training (PRT),
results in clinically meaningful gains in muscle mass, strength
and physical performance, even in very old individuals [ 66].
Exercise is also recognised as a primary and secondary pre-
vention strategy for hip fracture in older adults [ 67], with the
protective effect attributable to improvements in risk factors
for falls and fracture, including bone and muscle health, bal-
ance and mobility [ 68]. However, not all modalities are equal-
ly effective. Walking alone has little or no effect on preventing
bone and muscle loss [ 69], and while traditional PRT is effec-
tive at improving muscle mass, size and strength, it has mixed
effects on balance and function [ 70]. However, high-velocity
PRT (or power training), involving rapid concentric muscle
contractions, can improve muscle strength, power and BMD
in older adults [ 68], and high-challenging balance training
performed for at least 50 h is most effective for fall prevention
[70].
For sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity, the target outcomes
of any intervention should be to reduce fat mass while pre-
serving or improving muscle mass, strength and function. Ca-
loric restriction is effective for reducing body fat but also
causes losses in muscle and even bone mass [ 71, 72]. Com-
bining caloric restriction with multimodal programs that in-
corporate PRT and aerobic training may substantially amelio-
rate adverse effects on muscle and bone [ 73, 74••, 75–77]. For
instance, the findings from a 12-month factorial design ran-
domized controlled trial (RCT) of 107 obese adults aged
≥65 years randomised to a control group, weight loss, multi-
modal exercise (PRT, aerobic exercise, flexibility and balance
tasks) or both exercise and weight loss revealed that lean mass
Curr Osteoporos Rep


and hip BMD decreased less in the exercise and weight loss
group than the weight loss alone group [ 71]. Consistent with
these findings, reviews on exercise studies with and without
dietary or weight loss components in obese older adults report
that exercise programs including PRT and aerobic training
with modest caloric restriction are associated with greater im-
provements in body composition and functional performance
than either exercise or diet alone [ 78, 79].
To our knowledge, there are only two intervention studies
which have specifically targeted sarcopenic and dynapenic
obese older adults. In 21 sarcopenic obese adults aged 60 years
or older randomised to 15 weeks of strength/hypertrophy or
high speed (power) circuit training, no differences were ob-
served for changes in body fat and physical performance, but
lower-limb power tended to improve more for the circuit train-
ing group [ 80]. In a factorial design RCT involving 38 post-
menopausal women with dynapenic obesity randomised to
either 12-weeks of PRT, caloric restriction, both or a control
group, caloric restriction alone or in combination with PRT
was associated with an improvement in body weight, fat mass
and cardiometabolic health while PRT had a beneficial effect
on physical performance [ 81]. The findings from these small
trials are supportive of the concept that multimodal exercise
interventions incorporating PRT and combined with caloric
restriction are effective therapies for sarcopenic and dynapenic
obesity. However, further large-scale, long-term randomised
controlled trials are still needed to determine exercise training
doses that optimise multiple health outcomes in older adults
with these conditions.
Diet and Nutrition
Nutritional strategies, with a particular focus on energy
and protein intake, and vitamin D status, are recommend-
ed for the prevention and management of sarcopenia and
dynapenia in older adults [ 82]. It is well established that
age-related muscle loss occurs due to an imbalance be-
tween muscle protein synthesis (MPS) and muscle protein
breakdown (MPB). Dietary protein ingestion can stimu-
late MPS and inhibit MPB, resulting in a net positive
protein balance. Indeed, longitudinal studies have report-
ed that self-reported dietary p rotein intake is positively
and independently associated with muscle mass in older
adults [ 83–85]. However, the anabolic sensitivity of mus-
cle to protein feeding appears to be blunted during ageing
and so older adults may require higher protein doses to
stimulate MPS and prevent muscle loss [ 86]. There is also
considerable evidence that different protein sources vary
in their capacity to stimulate MPS, with whey protein
being more effective than either casein or soy [ 87]. Sup-
plementation with 20 –40 g of high-quality, rapidly
digested, leucine-rich protein can improve physical per-
formance in older adults [ 88], but a number of studies
have failed to observe any beneficial effects of protein
supplementation alone on muscle probably due to differ-
ences in the type, timing, dose and/or distribution of pro-
tein intake [ 89]. While further studies are needed to de-
termine optimal protein supplementation strategies for
older adults, a recent consensus statement recommends a
daily protein intake of 1.0 –1 . 2g / k gw i t ha tl e a s t2 0–25 g
of high-quality protein at each meal [ 90].
A concern with increasing dietary protein intake in the
case of sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity is that protein-
rich foods are often high in saturated fat and may therefore
exacerbate obesity. However, lean red meat, which is an
excellent source of protein and can stimulate a rise in MPS
at rest and after PRT [ 91], has been associated with reduc-
tions in body fat in an intervention using dietary interven-
tions to reduce intake of other macronutrients [ 92••]. There
is also some evidence that hi gh-protein diets can minimise
muscle mass losses associated with caloric restriction in
obese individuals [ 93]. Thus, while research is yet to con-
firm the effects of protein supplementation in sarcopenic
and dynapenic obese older adults, the fact that high-quality
protein can stimulate MPS without causing increases in
total energy intake suggests this dietary intervention holds
potential in these populations.
Vitamin D deficiency is common in older adults, and
prospective studies have shown that lower serum 25-
hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) concentrations are associated
with greater losses in muscle mass and strength and re-
duced physical performance in older adults [ 94, 95]. A
systematic review has concluded that vitamin D supple-
mentation may have a beneficial effect on proximal mus-
cle strength, although possibly only in those with low
vitamin D status [ 96]. Treatment with vitamin D has also
been associated with reductions in both fall and fracture
risk, possibly mediated by actions on skeletal muscle vi-
tamin D receptors and enhancing absorption of dietary
calcium and phosphate res ulting in increases in MPS
and improved bone health, respectively [ 97]. These find-
ings suggest that vitamin D supplementation may be ben-
eficial for treating sarc openia and dynapenia, with or
without obesity, as well as reducing fall and fracture risk,
in older adults.
Obesity is associated with vitamin D deficiency, and there
is some evidence that sarcopenic obese older adults have low-
er serum 25OHD levels than those who are obese only [ 98]. A
randomised controlled trial of 200 overweight adults with low
vitamin D status reported that supplementation of 3300 IU/
day vitamin D during a 12-month nutrition education inter-
vention did not enhance weight loss but reduced triglycerides
and systemic inflammation [99], which suggests correction of
vitamin D deficiency could potentially reduce the deleterious
effects of inflammation on muscle mass and function which
are considered a key component of the etiology of sarcopenic
Curr Osteoporos Rep


and dynapenic obesity [1]. It is therefore possible that vitamin
D supplementation may be beneficial in sarcopenia and
dynapenia, and particularly for older adults who are obese
given their risk of vitamin D deficiency, likely at doses
≥800 IU/day [ 100].
Combined Effects of Exercise and Nutrition
There is considerable interest in whether a combination of
these intervention strategies can produce a synergistic ef-
fect on individual components of sarcopenic and
dynapenic obesity. A meta-analysis has concluded that
protein supplementation >1.2 g/kg/d can enhance the ben-
efits of PRT on muscle mass and strength in young and
older adults [ 101], and this is consistent with other reports
[102, 103]. In a recent 4-month cluster randomised con-
trolled trial including 100 women residing in retirement
villages, PRT combined with 2×80 g serves of cooked
lean red meat consumed 6 days per week (equivalent to
a total dietary protein intake of ∼1.3 g/kg/d) resulted in
greater gains in muscle mass and strength relative to PRT
only and a decrease in fat mass [ 92••]. However, other
recent trials in older adults have failed to observe an
added benefit of protein supplementation over PRT alone
for muscle mass or strength [ 104, 105]. Further studies are
required to identify optimal protein types, doses and
timing for enhancing exercise-induced improvements in
body composition, muscle function, fall and fracture risk.
We have recently reported that older adults with high
vitamin D status and physical activity levels demonstrate
smaller gains in body fat over 5 years than those with
high vitamin D or physical activity levels alone [ 106].
This is consistent with exerci se interventions reporting
greater fat oxidation and physical performance improve-
ments in older adults who are vitamin D replete [ 107,
108]. However, a study of 96 vitamin D deficient older
adults performing 9 months of resistance training while
randomised to 400 IU/day per day of vitamin D plus cal-
cium or calcium alone did not report additional benefits of
vitamin D on physical performance [ 109], and 18 months
of low-fat vitamin
D-calcium fortified milk (800 IU/day)
did not enhance the effects of resistance training on mus-
cle size or function in older men with adequate vitamin D
status [ 110]. The lack of synergistic effects observed for
muscle mass and strength may be due to inadequate sam-
ple sizes, relatively low vitamin D doses, or failure to
target individuals with vitamin D deficiency, sarcopenia
and/or dynapenia [ 100]. There is similarly a lack of evi-
dence for vitamin D supplementation during exercise in-
terventions targeting weight loss in older adults. A
randomised controlled trial of postmenopausal women
completing a weight loss program for 12 months found
no differences in body composition between vitamin D
and placebo groups, although those that achieved
25OHD levels ≥80 nmol/L lost almost twice as much
body fat as those who did not [ 111].
Finally, a recent 13-week trial in 80 obese older adults
showed that a high whey-protein-, leucine-, and vitamin D-
enriched supplement (21 g protein and 800 IU vitamin D)
preserved muscle mass compared with isocaloric controls dur-
ing intentional weight loss combined with resistance training
[112••]. It is not possible to determine whether vitamin D or
protein is responsible for this effect, however, this finding
suggests that combining exercise for weight loss with vitamin
D and protein supplementation is potentially an effective treat-
ment for sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity.
sections.conclusion:
and Recommendations
There has been an exponential increase in research into
sarcopenia over the past two decades, but this has not trans-
lated into clinical practice, due to ongoing controversy re-
garding appropriate definitions, measurement techniques
and cut-points. The proposed shift of focus towards
dynapenia undoubtedly adds to this confusion, but is
rationalised by the evidence that muscle function is a stronger
predictor of health outcomes than muscle mass, and because
strength assessments may be more accessible to clinicians.
With the confluence of ageing and obese populations in many
societies, the prevalence of sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity
is likely to grow in the coming years. Although obesity may
be protective against some types of fractures, it appears that
increased adipose tissue may compromise bone quality, and
poor muscle mass and strength confer increased fall and frac-
ture risks for sarcopenic and dynapenic obese older adults.
Lifestyle interventions may be beneficial for improving mus-
cle mass and function, reducing adiposity, and increasing
bone quality in older adults. The most effective method for
preventing sarcopenia and dynapenia is multimodal exercise
including traditional and high-speed PRT, and this should
also be incorporated in weight loss interventions for
sarcopenic and dynapenic obese individuals, to avoid unde-
sirable losses in muscle and bone. In addition, to maintain or
increase muscle mass, older adults with sarcopenia or
dynapenia should be encouraged to consume at least
1.0 g/kg of high-quality protein per day (or more if complet-
ing exercise), and these levels should generally be maintained
at the expense of other macronutrients even during caloric
restriction for those with sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity.
Those with sarcopenia and dynapenia, and especially
sarcopenic and dynapenic obesity, should be considered at
risk for vitamin D deficiency, and supplementation of
≥800 IU/day cholecalciferol may be beneficial for those with
low vitamin D levels.
